scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-47 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-47 is a star with 0.96 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.94 times its radius. It is located 3343.16 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-47 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-47 system


Kepler-47 b

Kepler-47 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2012-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.29 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-47 b is 2.070 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-47 b is 3.050 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 0.4, and a semi-major axis of 0.2877 astronomical units, Kepler-47 b could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.


Kepler-47 c

Kepler-47 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2012-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.96 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-47 c is 3.170 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-47 c is 4.650 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 0.17, and a semi-major axis of 0.9638 astronomical units, Kepler-47 c could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.


Kepler-47 d

Kepler-47 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2019-05, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.70 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-47 d is 19.029 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-47 d is 7.040 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-47 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-47, which contains 3 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-47 - System With 3 Exolanets
